item.title: How a Village in Italy Became a Slice of Caracas
item.description: Generations of migrants from a village on the coast of southern Italy found a better life in Venezuela. Many came back and turned their town into a mini-Caracas.
item.dc:creator: Fabiola Ferrero

item.title: Laura Fernández Wins Costa Rican Presidency
item.description: Laura Fernández’s victory was driven by a crisis in which Costa Rica’s reputation for peace has been tarred by record-breaking violence.
item.dc:creator: Emiliano Rodríguez Mega and David Bolaños
item.media:credit: Cesar Rodriguez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Laura Fernández, Costa Rica’s president-elect, celebrating her election victory alongside supporters on Sunday evening.

item.title: Right-Wing Populist Holds Commanding Lead Ahead of Costa Rica’s Election
item.description: President Rodrigo Chaves’s handpicked successor has vowed to extend his agenda, which has sought to weaken democratic institutions and crack down on rising violence.
item.dc:creator: Emiliano Rodríguez Mega, David Bolaños and César Rodríguez
item.media:credit: Cesar Rodriguez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Laura Fernández at her closing campaign rally on Thursday night in San Antonio, Costa Rica.

item.title: Pierre Poilievre Is Retained as Leader of Canada’s Conservatives
item.description: Pierre Poilievre, a populist who led the Conservative Party to defeat last year, was retained as its leader on Friday, despite his dismal poll numbers.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi
item.media:description: Members of Canada’s Conservative Party voted overwhelmingly on Friday to keep Pierre Poilievre as their leader at a party convention in Calgary, Alberta.

item.title: Mark Carney Meets ‘Heated Rivalry’ Star Hudson Williams
item.description: Only one thing could make the TV show and cultural phenomenon “Heated Rivalry” more Canadian: pairing one of its stars, Hudson Williams, with Prime Minister Mark Carney in the nation’s capital.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:credit: Cole Burston for The New York Times
item.media:description: Prime Minister Mark Carney and Hudson Williams of “Heated Rivalry” on the red carpet in Ottawa.

item.title: U.N. Says It’s in Danger of Financial Collapse Because of Members’ Unpaid Dues
item.description: The world body warned it would run out of money by July and have to close its New York headquarters if countries, namely the United States, did not pay annual dues that amount to billions of dollars.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: The General Assembly in September. The U.N. secretary general, António Guterres, sent a letter to the ambassadors of all 196 member states on Thursday saying, “I cannot overstate the urgency of the situation we now face.”

item.title: Macaulay Culkin And Others Pay Tribute to Catherine O’Hara After Her Death
item.description: Videos and photos filled social media as fans shared their favorite scenes from O’Hara’s acting career and co-stars memorialized her.
item.dc:creator: Rylee Kirk
item.media:description: Catherine O’Hara in 2019. The actress died this week at the age of 71.

item.title: How Did This Beloved Rock From Canada End Up in California?
item.description: Climbers have used the 70-pound rock, which they call Portable, to practice balancing and gripping. Months after it went missing, it was found 19 hours away.
item.dc:creator: Adeel Hassan

item.title: Trump Moves to Cut All Oil to Cuba as U.S. Targets Its Government
item.description: President Trump’s threat to impose tariffs on any country that delivers oil to Cuba appeared to be directed largely at Mexico, the only nation that has sent any meaningful fuel shipments to the island.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles
item.media:description: The last shipment of oil to Cuba, from Mexico, arrived on Jan. 9, an analyst said.

item.title: Argentina in Advanced Talks to Become Destination for U.S. Deportations
item.description: Washington and Buenos Aires are working on an agreement to allow the U.S. to deport immigrants from other nations to the South American country.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola and Hamed Aleaziz
item.media:description: A plane landing in Buenos Aires last year. The talks come as the Trump administration has mobilized a sweeping and aggressive effort to curtail immigration.

item.title: Chevron Points to Venezuela’s Promise as Big Oil Earnings Fall
item.description: The two largest U.S. oil companies, Chevron and Exxon Mobil, reported their lowest annual profits in years.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca F. Elliott
item.media:credit: Micah Green for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Chevron refinery in Pascagoula, Miss.

item.title: International Companies Doing Business With ICE Are Taking Heat
item.description: A number of companies have found themselves facing questions about their work with Immigration and Customs Enforcement amid the agency’s intense operation in Minnesota.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:description: Roland Lescure, the French minister of finance and economy, told lawmakers he was seeking answers from a French firm whose American subsidiary last month inked a new deal with the Department of Homeland Security.

item.title: The Secret Sauce in ‘Heated Rivalry’? Canada.
item.description: The global television phenomenon is full of Canadian iconography and subsidized by Canadian taxpayers. On Thursday, it came home to celebrate.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Cole Burston
item.media:credit: Cole Burston for The New York Times
item.media:description: Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney and Heated Rivalry actor Hudson Williams on the red carpet at a conference for the Canadian Media Producers Association in Ottawa on Thursday.

item.title: Venezuelan Lawmakers Approve Sweeping Overhaul of Oil Sector
item.description: Bowing to Trump administration pressure, the new legislation improves conditions for foreign oil companies and opens the way to slash the taxes they pay.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A statue of a hand holding a drilling rig near Venezuela’s state oil company last year.

item.title: Canada Signs Auto Deal With South Korea, Moving Further from the U.S.
item.description: The agreement, while scarce on details, is the latest step by Prime Minister Mark Carney to reduce Canada’s reliance on trade with the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: Cars made by Kia Motors ready to be exported at the company’s shipping yard last year in Pyeongtaek, South Korea.

item.title: Rubio Says Venezuela Will Submit Monthly Budget to White House
item.description: Democrats sharply questioned the plan, including the role of Qatar in managing an account funded by the sale of Venezuelan oil.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio testified before the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations during a hearing to examine U.S. policy towards Venezuela.

item.title: Why the NORAD Cold War Pact Between the U.S. and Canada Is News
item.description: The State Department clarified comments made by the U.S. Ambassador to Canada that NORAD would be “altered” if that country did not purchase American F-35 jets.
item.dc:creator: Aimee Ortiz
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Center for Strategic and International Studies
item.media:description: Canada began a review of its agreement to buy F-35 fighter jets from the United States last year. The United States still wants Canada to use those jets for the common defense of North American airspace.

item.title: Plane Carrying Colombian Politicians Crashes in Area Contested by Rebels
item.description: The aircraft was carrying 15 people, and the authorities said there were no survivors.
item.dc:creator: Max Bearak
item.media:description: The aircraft that crashed was a Beechcraft 1900, similar to this one.

item.title: Dutch Court Orders Netherlands to Protect Bonaire From Climate Change
item.description: Bonaire, a Dutch overseas territory, deserves the same protections as Europe, the ruling said. The decision adds to a growing body of precedent worldwide.
item.dc:creator: Karen Zraick
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Marieke Vellekoop, director of Greenpeace Netherlands, center, with plaintiffs from Bonaire in court in The Hague in October.

item.title: How Computer Warfare Is Becoming Part of the Pentagon’s Arsenal
item.description: The military tested a new approach in Venezuela and during strikes on Iranian nuclear facilities.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and Adam Sella
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: The United States took power off-line in Caracas, Venezuela, to help military forces capture former President Nicolás Maduro this month.

item.title: Trinidadian Families File Wrongful Death Lawsuit Over Boat Strike by U.S. Military
item.description: The case tests the Trump administration’s argument that its extrajudicial killings of people suspected of smuggling drugs at sea have been lawful.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )
item.media:description: A memorial held by family members of Chad Joseph, one of two Trinidadian men whom the U.S. military apparently killed in a boat strike in the fall, in Las Cuevas, Trinidad and Tobago, in October.

item.title: Canada’s Marineland Whales Could Find New Homes in U.S.
item.description: Marineland, a closed aquatic park in Ontario, had threatened to euthanize its whales after the government denied an application to send them to China.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:description: Beluga whales in November at the now-closed Arctic Cove exhibit at Marineland, in Niagara Falls, Canada.

item.title: On Venezuela and Greenland, Many Trump Fans Give Him the Benefit of the Doubt
item.description: At least so far, President Trump has managed to bring along even those conservative supporters who are skeptical of foreign interventions.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Loren Elliott for The New York Times
item.media:description: A meeting of the Turning Point USA chapter last week at the University of Idaho in Moscow, Idaho.

item.title: In Venezuela, Freeing the Economy, but Nothing Else
item.description: Interim leader Delcy Rodríguez is liberalizing the economy without dismantling her predecessor’s repressive apparatus, raising questions about her aims.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Morning commuters in Caracas earlier this month.
